title: Patch Rundown: Worlds 2016
body: As the regions begin to mesh and practice with each other, strategies will become more refined and more polished. To break down what's to come, Dash, Scarra, Sheepy, and Zirene have gathered to discuss the patches leading up to Worlds and how Patch 6.18 will manifest on the year’s grandest stage.

replies.body: Wasn't interested in watching the Jungle video since it will always be {{champion:60}} {{champion:79}} {{champion:421}} .
Not at worlds. Elise will be near the top, but there won't be any Gragas, and Rek'Sai will be much lower priority. Graves, Nidalee, Skarner, Zac, Olaf and many others will be played in their stead.

Worlds scripted confirmed. 

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

Considering Elise was already considered a tier all to her own just below Gragas and Rek'Sai, I don't understand why she didn't also get nerfs when they did. Now it just goes from 2 junglers being clearly the best to 1 jungler just being better than the rest, which seems even worse.

It's still better. With the only clear top picks being Elise and Gnar, those two can be traded in pick/ban and each team will still hold at least one target ban. It really frees up the pre-game strats that can be worked around when blue side gets a free ban to spend.

How is trading Elise for Gnar any better than trading Rek'Sai for Gragas? If anything that seems worse. At least when you trade super strong jungler for super strong jungler, it's an even trade for both teams. Trading super strong jungler for super strong top laner just warps the top lane matchup.

It's better because by trading Rek'Sai or Gragas bans the second squad no longer automatically received a power duo like Sivir/Karma. Now, when there is (theoretically) only one clear S-tier in a given lane, it means teams can opt to either leave it open to trade the S-tier pick or ban it out and force an even pick/counter-pick from the A-tier for that position. It isn't much of a difference, but it at least gives teams an extra tool to work with in pick/ban. 

At the very least, having less than two power picks no longer locks you into a binary choice between one or the other. It allows for a lot more flexibility in terms of pocket picks and slot variety. It should also split the ban priority between the two positions so that teams can pick where to put their power. If we see Elise get traded for a Gnar pick/ ban in every game, so be it. At least we aren't 100% guaranteed to see the same matchup in every single game.

Was it really a goal to have no Gragas at all?  That's not what balance is.
Still, it's going to be a lot better than Mordeplank 2015 (never forget).  {{champion:82}} {{champion:41}} {{champion:114}} {{champion:122}} {{sticker:zombie-brand-facepalm}}

Last year i took all of my old Lego bricks and made a 86 x 86 board into a TSM logo and i have it hanging by my bed so you know i like both

I know it's an unpopular opinion, but I'm still not convinced that IMT is _clearly_ the better team. It's been twice in a row now that they came into Split finals with everything going for them and they still choked. They may have better individual talent and great team play to rival CLG's, but if CLG comes back in form--which they very well could--I don't see IMT being clearly better. Maybe somewhere on the same level.

Keep in mind, I really dislike CLG--this is not fanboyism speaking. I just don't see IMT standing in a clearly higher tier than them, and IMT has yet to prove that they truly are on a higher level. While their track record is short, it's been consistent.
Well put, ill take it

IMT is a team who looks really good when playing those weaker than them, but really bad when playing those better or equal to them. I don't want them going to Worlds because, as fun as they are, I think they'd be a trainwreck at Worlds since they clearly don't know how to deal with opposition.
